author: jgm
content:
<@499114472594604044> not sure that rewarding prior to genesis would help.  Is it to encourage those who otherwise would not stake?  Would 5% return over 6 months be something that would sway them? 10%?

The problem of going down the path of using financial levers to try to change behaviour is it rapidly becomes full of loopholes that encourage behaviour you didn't want and constrains future changes.  I think the idea of the returns curve is sound, it just needs some work done to ensure that the highs aren't too high and the lows aren't too low.  And if there is a single (theoretical) lever that moves the entire curve up and down if required that should be enough to fix things if they head out of whack.

(That said, I *do* think that the current validator system is not exactly encouraging to potential stakers; if I had to pick a single word to describe it I'd go for "violent".  Definitely a discussion to be had, but for a bit later on.)

author: jgm
content: Trouble with that curve is it has a minimum number of stakers; taking it back too far generates a lot of Ether in rewards.  For example, if there were only 1,024 validators in the queue they'd be picking up 90%+ annual returns.  With no requirement to do any work and no possibility to be slashed.  So it becomes an incentive to put a bit of Ether in there and hope that not enough is put in by others to trigger the chainstart, which doesn't sound like a great way to start (or not)
